questions.text: A detailed, complex Statement of Intention with intricate descriptions helps assessors understand your solo better.
questions.explanation: Keep your Statement of Intention concise and within the word limit. Intricate details that don't correspond to actual movement confuse assessors and make it harder to assess your work against the criteria.
questions.studyTip: Clear and concise beats long and complex. Assessors mark what they see.

questions.text: Your Statement of Intention should clearly outline the intention for each section of the dance.
questions.explanation: Assessors compare your written statement to your performance. Each section's intention must be clearly stated so they can identify how you communicate it through movement.
questions.studyTip: One clear intention per section—assessors need to see it in your movement.

questions.text: The formal structure description in your Statement of Intention can differ from your actual performance as long as it's interesting.
questions.explanation: Your documented formal structure must accurately match your actual performance. Inconsistencies between your statement and solo create confusion for assessors.
questions.studyTip: What you write must match what you dance. No surprises for assessors.

questions.text: Your Statement of Intention should describe the formal structure exactly as you perform it.
questions.explanation: Assessors use your statement as a guide. If the documented structure differs from the performance, they cannot effectively assess your choreographic choices.
questions.studyTip: Film your solo, then write—ensures your statement matches reality.

questions.text: Listing impressive-sounding choreographic devices is effective even if they're not clearly visible in your solo.
questions.explanation: Only list choreographic devices you actually use in your performance. Assessors look for evidence of each device you claim—if they can't see it, you lose credibility.
questions.studyTip: If you write it, they'll look for it. Make sure they can see it.

questions.text: Choreographic devices listed in your Statement of Intention should be clearly identifiable in your performance.
questions.explanation: Assessors match your documented devices to what they observe. Clear, visible application of stated devices demonstrates intentional choreographic choices.
questions.studyTip: List it, show it, make it obvious. No guessing games for assessors.

questions.text: You can finalise your costume close to the exam since the movement is what matters most.
questions.explanation: Always rehearse in your planned costume well before the exam. Unexpected costume issues during assessment impact your performance quality and demonstration of safe dance practice.
questions.studyTip: Rehearse in costume early and often—no surprises on exam day.

questions.text: Regularly rehearsing in your performance costume helps identify and resolve potential issues before the exam.
questions.explanation: Costume problems discovered during the exam are too late to fix. Regular costume rehearsals ensure your attire supports rather than hinders your performance.
questions.studyTip: Your costume is part of the performance. Train with it.

questions.text: Excelling in a few physical skills compensates for weaker demonstration of others.
questions.explanation: You must demonstrate all eight physical skills: alignment, balance, coordination, flexibility, strength, endurance, extension, and isolation. High-scoring performances show proficiency across all eight.
questions.studyTip: All 8 skills, not just your favourites. Check each one is visible.

questions.text: High-scoring performances demonstrate control of all eight physical skills within a diverse range of movements.
questions.explanation: Criteria 1–4 assess your control of all eight physical skills. Select movement that allows you to showcase alignment, balance, coordination, flexibility, strength, endurance, extension, and isolation.
questions.studyTip: Map your choreography—where does each physical skill appear?

questions.text: Attempting challenging movements beyond your current ability shows ambition and earns higher marks.
questions.explanation: Movements beyond your physical capabilities result in loss of control and precision. Select movements that align with your technical proficiency to ensure successful execution.
questions.studyTip: Clean execution beats ambitious failure. Know your limits.

questions.text: Selecting movements that match your technical ability allows you to demonstrate consistent control.
questions.explanation: Students who choose appropriate movement vocabulary showcase their abilities without compromising alignment, control, or safety. Technical proficiency with selected movements scores higher than struggling with difficult ones.
questions.studyTip: Choose what you can do well, not what you wish you could do.

questions.text: Focusing on your strongest movement categories is more effective than including movements from all six categories.
questions.explanation: Your skills-based solo must include actions from all six movement categories: locomotor, non-locomotor, elevation, rotation, falling, and stillness. Limited categories restrict your ability to demonstrate the full range of physical skills.
questions.studyTip: Six categories, six opportunities. Don't skip any.

questions.text: Diverse movement from all six categories provides more opportunities to demonstrate the eight physical skills.
questions.explanation: Each movement category offers different ways to show your physical skills. Including all six categories demonstrates versatility and allows assessors to see your full technical range.
questions.studyTip: Tick off each category: locomotor, non-locomotor, elevation, rotation, falling, stillness.

questions.text: Falling actions are effective for showing physical risk-taking regardless of how well you execute them.
questions.explanation: Falling actions often lead to issues with alignment and control of muscular strength if not properly trained. Include them only if you can execute them with control and safe technique.
questions.studyTip: Falling should look intentional, not accidental. Train it properly.

questions.text: Falling actions should only be included if you can execute them with controlled alignment and muscular strength.
questions.explanation: Poorly executed falling actions compromise Criterion 1 (alignment) and Criterion 2 (muscular strength). Master the technique before including these challenging movements.
questions.studyTip: Can you fall safely and stand up smoothly? If not, reconsider.

questions.text: Starting strong is most important since assessors form their impression early in the performance.
questions.explanation: Many students lack the fitness to maintain stamina and muscular strength throughout the whole performance and don't finish as strongly as they started. Consistent quality matters from start to finish.
questions.studyTip: If you fade at the end, your overall mark fades too.

questions.text: Building and maintaining fitness levels during rehearsal ensures consistent execution throughout the exam.
questions.explanation: Endurance is one of the eight physical skills. Your performance must demonstrate sustained quality. Focus on cardio and strength conditioning leading up to the exam.
questions.studyTip: Run your solo twice in a row. If the second one suffers, train harder.

concepts.title: Acrobatic skills must serve the dance

questions.text: Including impressive acrobatic skills will boost your marks by demonstrating advanced physical ability.
questions.explanation: Acrobatic skills that don't enhance the interpretation or demonstrate safe dance practice actually reduce marks. Skills must serve the choreographic intention, not just impress.
questions.studyTip: Ask: does this trick serve my dance, or just my ego?

questions.text: Acrobatic skills should enhance interpretation of your intention and demonstrate safe dance practice.
questions.explanation: Every movement choice, including acrobatics, must connect to your intention and be executed safely. Random tricks interrupt flow and suggest weak choreographic decision-making.
questions.studyTip: If you remove the trick, does anything change? Keep only purposeful movement.

questions.text: Matching the tempo of your music consistently shows musicality and connection to your accompaniment.
questions.explanation: Only matching the rhythm/tempo of the music shows limited manipulation of time. High-scoring performances work both with and against the music's accents and tempo changes to create variation.
questions.studyTip: With the music AND against it—both show skill.

questions.text: Working both with and against musical accents and tempo changes demonstrates skilled manipulation of time.
questions.explanation: Variation in your use of time creates interest and expression. Sometimes align with the music, sometimes deliberately contrast it. This shows intentional choreographic choice.
questions.studyTip: Find three moments to go against the music. It shows control.

questions.text: Arm movements are the primary way to create interesting shapes in dance.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring performances rely too heavily on arm-based shapes. High-scoring performances use shapes that involve the whole body—torso, legs, and head, not just arms.
questions.studyTip: Cover your arms—is your shape still interesting?

questions.text: Effective shape manipulation involves the whole body, not just the arms.
questions.explanation: Assessors look for varied body shapes across your entire form. Engage your spine, hips, and legs in creating curved and angular shapes throughout your solo.
questions.studyTip: Torso shapes the phrase. Arms just finish it.

questions.text: Maintaining consistent energy quality throughout your solo creates a unified performance.
questions.explanation: Consistent energy quality results in monotony. High-scoring performances manipulate energy with variations of force (strong/light) and flow (bound/free) throughout the phrases and sections.
questions.studyTip: Energy contrast = audience engagement. Monotone = boredom.

questions.text: Varying force and flow throughout your solo demonstrates skilled manipulation of energy.
questions.explanation: Energy manipulation means changing between strong and light force, bound and free flow. These contrasts create expression and demonstrate control over dynamics.
questions.studyTip: Label your sections: sharp? sustained? explosive? flowing? Mix them up.

questions.text: Looking at the floor or your body helps you focus on executing movements correctly.
questions.explanation: Looking down suggests under-preparation and lack of confidence. High-scoring performances maintain confident eye contact and project the whole body to communicate with the audience throughout.
questions.studyTip: Eyes down = confidence down. Lift your focus.

questions.text: Maintaining eyeline and whole-body projection throughout demonstrates artistry and communicates intention to the audience.
questions.explanation: Projection skills are essential for Criterion 8. Use your eyeline purposefully—where you look directs audience attention and communicates meaning.
questions.studyTip: Your eyeline tells a story. Make it intentional.

questions.text: Pausing between sections gives assessors time to recognise your formal structure.
questions.explanation: Abrupt stops or awkward pauses between phrases and sections lower artistry marks. High-scoring performances present smooth transitions that maintain the flow and intention.
questions.studyTip: Transitions are choreography too. Rehearse them.

questions.text: Smooth transitions between phrases and sections enhance the cohesion of your performance.
questions.explanation: How you move between sections matters as much as the sections themselves. Seamless transitions show preparation and artistic control.
questions.studyTip: Film yourself—watch only the transitions. Are they dance or just... pauses?

questions.text: Choreographic processes include improvisation, rehearsal, and performance.
questions.explanation: The five choreographic processes are: Improvisation, Selection, Arrangement, Refinement, and Evaluation (ISARE). Rehearsal and performance are separate categories of processes.
questions.studyTip: ISARE: Improvisation, Selection, Arrangement, Refinement, Evaluation.

questions.text: The choreographic processes are improvisation, selection, arrangement, refinement, and evaluation.
questions.explanation: These five processes (ISARE) describe how you create movement vocabulary. Written exam questions often ask you to describe how you used these to compose your solo.
questions.studyTip: ISARE creates movement. Other processes prepare it for performance.

questions.text: Repeating movement to develop muscle memory is a choreographic process.
questions.explanation: Repetition for muscle memory is a rehearsal process, not a choreographic process. Choreographic processes (ISARE) are about creating and shaping movement, not preparing it for performance.
questions.studyTip: Creating movement = choreographic. Practising movement = rehearsal.

questions.text: Choreographic processes describe how you create movement, while rehearsal processes describe how you prepare it for performance.
questions.explanation: A common exam error is confusing these. Choreographic: improvising, selecting, arranging, refining, evaluating. Rehearsal: repeating, marking, receiving feedback, building muscle memory.
questions.studyTip: Ask: am I making movement or practising movement? Different processes.

concepts.title: Link processes to correct dance work

questions.text: When describing processes, you can refer to any solo you performed during the year.
questions.explanation: Exam questions specify which dance work to discuss—skills-based solo, cohesive composition, or learnt dance. Referring to the wrong solo scores zero for that question.
questions.studyTip: Read the question: which solo? Skills? Composition? Learnt? Wrong one = zero.

questions.text: You must refer to the specific solo dance work named in each exam question.
questions.explanation: Each question specifies which work to discuss. Even if your answer is technically correct, referring to the wrong dance work means you haven't answered what was asked.
questions.studyTip: Highlight or circle the dance work named in each question before answering.

questions.text: Including many different choreographic devices shows sophisticated choreographic skill.
questions.explanation: Choreographic devices must clearly support your dance idea. Work that considers how devices support the intention scores higher than work with random devices scattered throughout.
questions.studyTip: Why this device here? If you can't answer, reconsider.

questions.text: Choreographic devices should clearly support your intention and help structure the sections of your dance.
questions.explanation: Devices like repetition, contrast, and motif development should serve a purpose. Can assessors see how each device contributes to communicating your intention?
questions.studyTip: Each device should earn its place. Purpose over quantity.

questions.text: A motif is any movement phrase that you repeat in your solo.
questions.explanation: A well-formed motif is a distinctive movement idea that captures your intention, not just any repeated phrase. It should be recognisable when manipulated and developed throughout your solo.
questions.studyTip: Would someone recognise your motif even when varied? That's well-formed.

questions.text: Well-formed motifs capture your intention and remain recognisable when manipulated throughout the dance.
questions.explanation: Strong motifs connect to your intention and provide material for development. Assessors should be able to track your motif as you vary it using choreographic devices.
questions.studyTip: Your motif is your theme. Develop it, don't just repeat it.

questions.text: Spatial arrangement can be varied freely as long as the movement vocabulary stays consistent.
questions.explanation: Spatial organisation must support the intention of each section. Poor spatial planning that doesn't connect to your intention results in incoherent choreography.
questions.studyTip: Space tells story. Random spacing = random meaning.

questions.text: Level, direction, eye/body focus, and dimension should be arranged to support your intention for each section.
questions.explanation: Criteria 4–7 assess your manipulation of spatial organisation. Each element should be chosen deliberately to help communicate what each section is about.
questions.studyTip: For each section: What level? What direction? What focus? What size? Why?

questions.text: Changing levels frequently shows good use of the spatial element of level.
questions.explanation: Effective use of level means choosing levels that support your intention. High, medium, and low levels should communicate meaning, not just add variety for its own sake.
questions.studyTip: Level should mean something. Low = grounded? High = aspiration? Choose deliberately.

questions.text: Level choices should communicate meaning that supports your intention.
questions.explanation: Each level carries associations. Use level changes to reinforce what each section communicates. Random level changes without purpose weaken your choreographic choices.
questions.studyTip: Can you explain why this section is low and that section is high?

questions.text: Using all areas of the stage demonstrates effective use of direction.
questions.explanation: Direction is about more than coverage. Directional choices—facing, travelling paths, orientation—should support your intention and help structure sections clearly.
questions.studyTip: Where you go and where you face both communicate. Plan both.

questions.text: Directional choices including facing and pathways should be planned to support each section's intention.
questions.explanation: Consider which way you face, which direction you travel, and how this relates to your intention. Direction can create dynamics like advance, retreat, or confrontation.
questions.studyTip: Downstage = engagement. Upstage = retreat. Use the space meaningfully.

questions.text: Making movements as big as possible shows confident use of personal dimension.
questions.explanation: Personal dimension (size of movement) should vary to support intention. Some sections may need contained, small movements while others need expansive ones. Constant large movement becomes monotonous.
questions.studyTip: Big isn't always better. Size should serve the moment.

questions.text: Varying the size of movements between contained and expansive supports different intentions within your solo.
questions.explanation: Personal dimension is one of the spatial elements assessors evaluate. Contrast between small and large movements creates visual interest and helps distinguish sections.
questions.studyTip: Whisper some movements. Shout others. Contrast creates impact.

questions.text: Your costume choice is purely an artistic decision that doesn't affect assessment criteria.
questions.explanation: Inappropriate attire that doesn't allow body alignment to be shown (Criterion 4) or impedes safe dance practice affects your marks. Assessors need to see your body's alignment clearly.
questions.studyTip: Can assessors see your alignment? That's your costume test.

questions.text: Your costume should allow assessors to clearly see your body's alignment throughout the performance.
questions.explanation: Criterion 4 requires demonstration of alignment. Very loose or flowing costumes may hide alignment issues but also prevent assessors from awarding marks for good alignment.
questions.studyTip: Your body is your instrument. Don't hide it.

questions.text: Small jewellery items are acceptable if they're part of your costume design.
questions.explanation: Jewellery poses safety risks during physical movement and indicates lack of knowledge about safe dance practice. Remove all jewellery before your assessment.
questions.studyTip: Jewellery off. No exceptions. Safety first.

questions.text: Removing all jewellery before performing demonstrates understanding of safe dance practice.
questions.explanation: Safe dance practice is assessed throughout your performance. Wearing jewellery signals you haven't considered the risks of physical movement, regardless of your costume concept.
questions.studyTip: If it dangles, catches, or could scratch—remove it.

questions.text: Any footwear that matches your costume aesthetic is appropriate for the exam.
questions.explanation: Slippery or inappropriate footwear prevents demonstration of safe dance practice and can compromise movement execution. Choose footwear that supports your technical requirements.
questions.studyTip: Fashion follows function. Your feet need grip.

questions.text: Footwear should support safe dance practice and allow secure execution of your choreography.
questions.explanation: Appropriate footwear is part of safe dance practice. Whether barefoot, socked, or in dance shoes, ensure you can execute all movements safely and with control.
questions.studyTip: Rehearse in your exam footwear. No surprises on the day.

questions.text: Learning processes include repetition, feedback, and refinement.
questions.explanation: Refinement is a choreographic process, not a learning process. Learning processes include: imitating movement, watching the choreographer, receiving feedback, repetition for muscle memory, and watching video of movement.
questions.studyTip: Learning = acquiring movement. Refinement = improving your own choreography.

questions.text: Learning processes for a learnt dance include imitating movement and watching the choreographer demonstrate.
questions.explanation: When learning a group dance, you use processes like imitation, observation, feedback, and repetition. These are different from choreographic processes because you're learning someone else's movement.
questions.studyTip: Learnt dance = someone else's choreography. Learning processes help you acquire it.

questions.text: Rehearsal processes and learning processes are interchangeable terms.
questions.explanation: Learning processes help you acquire movement vocabulary. Rehearsal processes prepare movement for performance—they include repetition, marking, video review, and feedback to refine execution.
questions.studyTip: Learn it first. Then rehearse it. Different stages, different processes.

questions.text: Rehearsal processes focus on preparing learnt movement for performance through repetition and feedback.
questions.explanation: Once movement is learnt, rehearsal processes polish it for performance. These include building muscle memory, checking spacing, refining timing, and preparing for performance conditions.
questions.studyTip: Rehearsal = performance preparation. Don't confuse it with learning.

questions.text: Spacing issues in group work can be fixed during performance through visual awareness.
questions.explanation: Correct spacing must be established through rehearsal processes—marking pathways, using mirrors, receiving feedback, and repetition. Relying on visual adjustment during performance leads to errors.
questions.studyTip: Rehearse spacing until it's automatic. Performance isn't for fixing.

questions.text: Rehearsal processes like marking pathways and using mirrors help establish accurate spacing before performance.
questions.explanation: Spatial accuracy in group work requires specific rehearsal—slowly marking floor pathways, using mirrors to check formations, receiving choreographer feedback, and building muscle memory of correct positions.
questions.studyTip: Know your spot without looking. That's what rehearsal builds.

questions.text: Performance practices include repeating movement and receiving feedback from your teacher.
questions.explanation: Repetition and feedback are rehearsal processes. Performance practices occur during the actual performance: projection, facial expression, spatial awareness, musical awareness, and technical execution.
questions.studyTip: Performance practices happen WHILE performing. Rehearsal comes before.

questions.text: Performance practices that enhance artistry include projection, expression, and awareness of spatial markers.
questions.explanation: During performance, you use practices like projecting to the audience, expressing through face and body, being aware of space, responding to musical accents, and executing with technical accuracy.
questions.studyTip: What do you actually DO while performing? Those are performance practices.

questions.text: Writing everything you know about processes demonstrates thorough understanding.
questions.explanation: Answer only what's asked. If the question asks about choreographic processes, don't write about rehearsal or performance processes. If it asks about your composition solo, don't discuss your skills solo.
questions.studyTip: Read the question twice. Answer what's asked, nothing more.

questions.text: Each question specifies which processes and which dance work to discuss—answer only those.
questions.explanation: Questions are precise: 'choreographic processes for your cohesive composition' or 'rehearsal processes for the learnt dance'. Mixing these up scores zero even if your content is correct.
questions.studyTip: Highlight: which processes? Which dance work? Answer exactly that.

questions.text: Defining a process correctly is enough to score full marks.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses identify the process AND explain how it was used with specific examples from your solo. Include actual movement vocabulary or intentions that resulted from using the process.
questions.studyTip: Define it, then prove you used it. Specific examples matter.

questions.text: High-scoring responses include examples of specific movement or intentions that resulted from using each process.
questions.explanation: Don't just say 'I used refinement.' Explain what you refined and how—'I refined my opening motif by seeking feedback about conveying my intention of...'
questions.studyTip: General = low marks. Specific = high marks. Show what YOU did.

concepts.title: Link to intention and spatial organisation

questions.text: Discussing processes in isolation demonstrates clear understanding of each one.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses link processes to how they helped communicate the intention or use spatial organisation. Show connections between the process and your choreographic choices.
questions.studyTip: Always link back: how did this process help communicate your intention?

questions.text: Strong responses connect processes to how they helped create movement that communicated the intention.
questions.explanation: Assessors reward understanding of how processes serve the bigger picture. 'I used selection to choose movements that clearly conveyed my intention of...' shows deep understanding.
questions.studyTip: Process → movement → intention. Show the chain.

questions.text: Personal opinions about prescribed solo works demonstrate independent thinking and earn marks.
questions.explanation: Prescribed solo analysis requires discussing documented influences on the choreographer's choices. Research the choreographer, their background, context, and how these influenced intention and movement vocabulary.
questions.studyTip: Research the work. Know the choreographer. Opinions aren't analysis.

questions.text: Analysing prescribed solos requires research into influences on the choreographer's choices about intention and movement.
questions.explanation: Questions ask about influences (plural) on the choreographer. High-scoring responses provide in-depth discussion of how, when, and where the choreographer was exposed to each influence.
questions.studyTip: Know at least three influences for your prescribed solo. Research deeply.

concepts.title: Explain impact, not just list influences

questions.text: Listing several influences on a choreographer demonstrates thorough knowledge of the work.
questions.explanation: Listing influences without explaining their impact scores low. You must discuss how each influence affected the choreographer's choices about intention, movement vocabulary, or production aspects.
questions.studyTip: Influence → impact. What did the influence cause? That's what matters.

questions.text: High-scoring responses explain how each influence impacted the choreographer's choices about the dance work.
questions.explanation: For each influence, explain the impact: 'This influence led the choreographer to create angular, sharp movements that represented...' Don't just name influences—show their effect.
questions.studyTip: Name it, then explain what it changed. Impact is worth more than identification.

questions.text: A cohesive dance flows continuously without clear section breaks.
questions.explanation: Cohesion doesn't mean no sections. Your solo needs clearly structured sections that transition into each other. Each section must be more than one phrase of movement.
questions.studyTip: Sections create structure. Transitions create cohesion. You need both.

questions.text: A cohesive composition requires clear sections, each containing more than one phrase of movement.
questions.explanation: Criteria require clear formal structure with distinct sections. Each section explores part of your intention. Sections should be recognisable even while transitioning smoothly between them.
questions.studyTip: Can you name your sections? If not, they're not clear enough.

questions.text: Ending when your music ends creates a natural conclusion to your solo.
questions.explanation: Many students finish abruptly or don't incorporate an ending that brings the dance to a clear conclusion. Your ending should resolve the dance intentionally, not just stop when the music does.
questions.studyTip: Choreograph your ending. Don't just... stop.

questions.text: An effective ending brings your solo to a clear, choreographed conclusion that resolves the intention.
questions.explanation: Your ending is the last impression assessors have. It should feel intentional and connected to your overall intention, not like you ran out of choreography or time.
questions.studyTip: Your ending should feel inevitable, not accidental.

questions.text: Using multiple music tracks demonstrates varied musical interpretation.
questions.explanation: Too many tracks in a short work or unsympathetic editing impedes cohesion. If using multiple tracks, ensure editing supports rather than disrupts your solo's unity.
questions.studyTip: More tracks ≠ better. Unity matters more than variety.

questions.text: Music choice should support cohesion—multiple tracks require careful editing to maintain unity.
questions.explanation: Music should enhance your intention, not fragment it. If you edit tracks together, ensure the transitions serve your choreographic structure. Jarring edits suggest poor planning.
questions.studyTip: Listen to your music edit without dancing. Does it flow?

questions.text: Choreographing in a lyrical style that interprets song lyrics shows emotional connection to your music.
questions.explanation: Some students choreograph lyrical style that interprets music lyrics rather than addressing criteria. Your solo must demonstrate the assessment criteria, not just respond emotionally to lyrics.
questions.studyTip: Criteria first, lyrics second. You're assessed on criteria, not emotion.

questions.text: Your choreographic choices should address the assessment criteria, not just interpret your music's lyrics.
questions.explanation: A clear intention that addresses criteria accesses higher marks. Your movement should demonstrate spatial organisation, choreographic devices, and communication of intention—not just match lyrics.
questions.studyTip: Check your solo against criteria, not against your song.
